content.description:
This small formation is a fun, short climbing outing if in the area. P1- start up loose, blocky chimney and head left when possible on low angle ramp. This was a pretty moderate pitch (5.3?) and felt comfortable to solo.-50ft

P2- Jam 5.7 handcrack for 15ft, and head right to obvious ledge. Clip pin and make 1 aid move (step in etriers) to top of formation and rap anchor. -40ft

You can now sit back and take in views of the colorado river, and the surrounding desert landscape-you will likely not be disappointed....
content.protection: Single set of cams, 60m rope, 1 etrier (or over-the-shoulder sling would work).
content.location:
From Rte. 128 (River road) head north on dirt road a few hundred feet upriver of Dewey bridge. The road has a sign indicating a junction with the Kokopelli Mountainbike trail. Drive through Cattlegate and continue about a mile until the tower

comes into view.  Road becomes rough near the towers, so park before switchbacks. Route is on west facing side of formation. Warning: Tower is labeled incorrectly in Desert rock III book.

content.description:
This route isn't super classic but is a fun little jaunt. Plus it's a tower. Sort of...

Start up a slightly chossy seam that opens up for a cam placement or two. Gain the big ledge, get a few more cams in, and mantle the horizontal pillar sticking out of the base of the fin proper. Place a nut (take your nut tool to get all of the sand out of the crack), make a move or two, place the red Camalot down and to your right, then make a couple more moves to the top.

Getting to the ledge is 5.6, the mantle is 5.easy, and the rest to the top is 5.easier.
content.protection: I used .4 (purple,) .5 (green), 1 (red), 3 (blue), and 4 (old style purple) Camalots, plus a #5 Stopper. The #4 Camalot wasn't necessary but I had it with me and figured I'd place it. There's a sling and a quicklink around the top of the formation. I'd recommend taking a longer sling (the one I used was tied out of a 9' piece of webbing) so that it can go around some better rock a few inches lower...
content.location: The formation is to the south of Fear and Loathing, along the same ridge. The route starts on the west face at an obvious seam.

content.description: A steep 5.9 start leading to a run out, marginally protected, frictiony 5.7 slab.  The route gets 5 stars in the DR III guide, but I only thought it was OK.
content.protection: Small nuts and friends.  I backed up one drilled angle with another nut at the top.
content.location: directly next to the road where the white sandstone comes within feet of the road.  DRIII describes it as being 500' of Feasant Plucker.
